Influence of precipitation conditions on precursor particle size distribution and activity of Cu/ZnO methanol synthesis catalyst Bahman Vasheghani Farahani a ⁎ Farzaneh Hosseinpour Rajabi a Mohsen Bahmani a Marzieh Ghelichkhani b Saeed Sahebdelfar b a Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Imam Khomeini International University, P.O. Box 288, Qazvin 34149, Iran Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Imam Khomeini International University P.O. Box 288 Qazvin 34149 Iran b Catalyst Research Group, Petrochemical Research and Technology Company, National Petrochemical Company, (NPC-RT) P.O. Box 14965/115, Tehran, Iran Catalyst Research Group, Petrochemical Research and Technology Company, National Petrochemical Company (NPC-RT) P.O. Box 14965/115 Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 912 381 1743; fax: +98 28 33780084. Graphical abstract Binary Cu/ZnO methanol synthesis catalysts were prepared by the co-precipitation of copper and zinc hydroxycarbonates using different initial solution concentrations, stirring rates and aging times and temperatures during precipitation, and different calcination temperatures of the precipitated hydroxycarbonates. The precipitates (catalyst precursors), fresh catalyst and were characterized at appropriate stages by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), N2O chemisorption and particle size distributions measurement techniques. All catalysts were tested for methanol synthesis activity in fixed-bed reactor under conditions similar to that of commercial operation (503K, 50bar and GHSV of 17,250h−1), using of H2, CO, and CO2 (80/12/8mol ratio) mixture as the feed. During aging of the precursor, a sharp pH drop along with color change (from blue to green) was observed after certain aging time. Further, the particle size of precursors showed a decrease after color change. The time of this change was strongly dependent on the aging temperature and decreased by increasing aging temperature. At 40°C aging temperature, the catalyst activity increased with aging time but the resulting catalyst exhibited poor performance because the color change did not occur even after 65h of aging of the mother liquor. At 80°C aging temperature, a color change took place rapidly after about 0.5–0.75h of aging, and the catalyst activity increased with aging time followed by a decrease upon further aging. At a constant aging time of 5h, the catalyst activity increased with temperature in the range of 40–60°C and then decreased when temperature rose further from 60 to 80°C. The highest methanol synthesis activity (555gMeOH/kgcat h) was observed for the catalyst prepared from 1M initial solution, 500rpm stirring rate and aged at 60°C. This was attributed to the small CuO crystallite size and large Cu surface area of the resulting catalyst. Keywords Methanol synthesis Cu/ZnO catalyst Particle size Aging time Aging temperature 1 Introduction Methanol is an important chemical and a potential energy carrier in the future [1]. The commercial ternary Cu/ZnO-based catalysts have high activity and selectivity toward methanol from synthesis gas [2]. The catalyst for this process has been an important area of research in order to improve the catalyst performance [3]. The catalyst is typically prepared by co-precipitation method followed by calcination and reduction. The precipitation conditions such as the precipitation temperature, pH of precipitation, concentration of initial solutions [4,5], addition of promoters [6–8] and the duration of aging of precursor play a significant role on the performance of the catalyst [9,10]. The aging of the precipitated Cu–Zn hydroxycarbonates (that is, catalyst precursors) has a strong influence on the catalytic properties of the resulting Cu/ZnO catalysts. Increased catalytic activity as a result of continued precipitate aging has been demonstrated for methanol synthesis and reverse water gas shift reactions [11]. Although the performance of copper catalysts obtained from aged precursors have been investigated [5,9], the influence of aging time and temperature, their interaction and also their effects on precursor particle size distribution and activity relationship have not yet been recognized. Particle shape, like particle size, can directly influence catalyst performance and its measurement can be used to predict the catalyst performance. Often, manufacturers of particulate products measure and use it to assess the differences between batches, either for product development reasons or for quality control purposes. This work focuses on the correlation between the particle size of the precipitate and the activity of copper catalysts prepared by different aging times and temperatures and other preparation conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of binary Cu/ZnO catalyst samples were prepared by a co-precipitation method under different aging temperatures and different aging times of precursors in mother liquor. Some additional important preparation parameters were further changed (Table 1 ). A mixed nitrate solution of 1.0mol/l copper nitrate and 1.0mol/l zinc nitrate, (prepared separately by dissolution of basic copper carbonate and zinc oxide in appropriate amount of nitric acid solution, respectively) with Cu:Zn ratio=2:1 and a solution of 1.0mol/l Na2CO3 as a precipitant were pumped into a stirred and heated glass reactor containing 250ml of demineralized water. During precipitation process the metal nitrate solution was pumped continuously, at constant flow rate of 5ml/min, while the pH, temperature and aging time were monitored and controlled. The sodium carbonate solution was added to maintain a constant pH=7, controlled by a CONSORT R305 pH meter. The co-precipitation was stopped when 200ml of metal nitrate solution was added. The pH increased during the subsequent aging process. After aging, the precipitate (copper zinc hydroxycarbonate precursors) was filtered and washed three times with 800ml of demineralized water under continuous stirring at 328K for 15, 30, 45min, respectively and then dried overnight at 100°C. The residual sodium amount in the catalyst was checked by the analysis of decanted water from the last washing step for sodium content which was typically below 60ppm. Finally, the dried precipitate was calcined at 600 or 700K in tubular furnace under continuous air flow for 3.5h (5K/min). The catalyst names and compositions of metal oxides in final samples are also given in Table 1. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The particle size distribution of the precursors (dispersed in demineralized water) was measured using Mastersizers 2000 of Malvern Instruments Company. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a BrukerD8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using CuKα1 radiation. XRD patterns were recorded in the range of 2θ =10–80°. The crystallite size of CuO in calcined catalyst was estimated from the full width at half maximum of the basic CuO XRD peaks [2θ =38.8, (111)+(200)] using the Scherrer equation. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were performed using a NOVA Quantachrome 2200 High-Speed Gas Sorption Analyzer, version 7.11. Before analysis, samples were prepared under N2 gas flow at 150°C for 2h. Isotherms were recorded at 77K. N2-physisorption was used to characterize the surface area. The BET surface area was calculated from the multi-point adsorption data in the relative pressure interval from 0.05 to 0.25. The copper surface area was calculated using the nitrous oxide chemisorption method according to 2 Cu ( s ) + N 2 O ( g ) → Cu 2 O ( s ) + N 2 ( g ) assuming a value of 1.46×1019 Cu surface atoms/m2 for the copper surface atom density [12–14]. The catalyst was first reduced and then cooled to chemisorption temperature (338K). A flow of N2O gas was fed into the reactor and the effluent gas from catalyst bed was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Nitrogen evolved by the reaction was computed via peak area from TCD-signal. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) measurements of the catalysts were performed in the range of 298–600K using a continuous flow apparatus using U shape quartz micro-reactor fed with a 6.5% H2/Ar mixture at 40ml/min and heating rate of 5K/min. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The performance of the catalyst samples for methanol synthesis was tested in a lab-scale, high pressure, tubular, fixed-bed reactor at 5.0MPa and 503K. One gram of the catalysts within 16 and 25 mesh size (mixed with the same mesh size of SiC in volume ratio of 1:3 of catalyst to SiC for uniform temperature distribution in the bed) was loaded in a stainless steel reactor (I.D.=10mm) and reduced in diluted H2 (10% in N2) flow at 523K and atmospheric pressure for 14h before syngas feed introduction. The feed gas consisted of 80vol% H2, 12vol% CO, and 8vol% CO2. The total gas flow was 250Nml/min. Under this condition, the space velocity was much higher than those of commercial-scale reactors, so the reactor effluent composition was very far from thermodynamic equilibrium composition. The methanol, water and oxygenate byproducts as well as H2, CO, CO2 and small amount of CH4 gases were analyzed on a Varian Star CP-3800 online gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization and thermal conductivity detector and two columns (capillary column HP-Plot Al2O3/Na2SO4, 50m, 0.53mm, 15μm and packed column Mol. sieve 13X (1/8inch) Hysep Q (1/8inch). The gas chromatograph was connected to the effluent of reactor by heat tracing line at 150°C. 3 Results and discussion Table 2 summarizes the structural properties of the precursors and catalysts as well as their activities in methanol synthesis. An overview of the table shows that the catalyst performance (in terms of space time yield, STY) is strongly influenced by precursor preparation conditions, with samples did not exhibit color change showing the poorest catalytic performance in methanol synthesis. It can be seen that for CZ03 and CZ07 catalysts the Cu surface area is unexpectedly close to the BET surface area. Similar results have been reported by other authors [10,15–18]. This could be explained by the fact that for BET surface area measurements, unreduced catalysts were used whereas, for that of the copper surface, the copper oxides were firstly reduced to metallic state, after which the surface area measurement by N2O passivation was performed. Therefore, the catalyst compositions and structures were not the same for the two measurements. Consequently, the copper surface area of the reduced catalyst could be close to BET surface area of the catalyst because the surface area of the catalyst could be increased by reduction [8]. It is also interesting to note that the values of Cu particle sizes calculated from the copper surface (assuming a spherical model [19]) are in agreement with those obtained by XRD peak analysis. During aging of the precipitates, a sharp pH drop was observed accompanied with a color change (from blue to green) after certain aging time (Fig. 1 ). Crystallization to zincian-malachite [(Cu,Zn)2(OH)2CO3] and aurichalcite [(Cu,Zn)5(OH)6(CO3)2] begin simultaneously coinciding with the pH drop corroborating that this effect is a direct indicator for the transformation of the solid [5,20]. Fig. 2 shows XRD patterns of the catalyst precursors at 80°C of aging temperature before and after color change. Before color change due to aging, no distinct peak is observed in the XRD pattern, indicating the absence of a crystalline phase. However, after color change, the peaks related to co-precipitated hydroxylcarbonates such as malachite, zincian-malachite and aurichalcite are observed, indicating the transformation of the amorphous phase to crystalline phase. As Table 1 and Fig. 1 illustrates, color change and sharp pH drop was not observed for samples aged at 40°C within the aging time employed. This could be explained by the very slow rate of phase-transformation at this lower level of aging temperature. At 60 and 80°C, however, the color change and sharp pH drop was observed for most samples except for those with very short aging times. At 80°C, pH drop was very sharp due to rapid phase-transformation at this high level of aging temperature. 3.1 Particle size distribution Fig. 3a shows a plot of particle size distribution (PSD) of the hydroxycarbonate precursors using different aging times at 40°C. As aging time increased, the size of precursor particles showed an increase followed by a decrease of particle size. Color change was not observed even after 65h of aging at this temperature, and no change took place in phase composition of precursor. The observed increase during 5–18h of aging time could be due to slow dissolution of the smaller or sol particles and redeposition on larger particles (that is Ostwald ripening [21]). With further aging up to 65h, one observes the PSD slightly shifts to lower diameters which could be due to approach to color change point which is accompanied with decreasing of particle size. Fig. 3b shows a plot of PSD of precursors after different aging times at 80°C. At this temperature, color change of precursors occurred within 0.5–0.75h of aging and the PSD of precursor shifted to lower levels after color change due to change in phase and composition of catalyst precursor. As already mentioned, aging of the precipitates was accompanied by spontaneous crystallization of the initially amorphous, blue precipitate to the crystalline blue-green form [9]. The crystallized precursors have smaller particle size than the initial amorphous precipitates. The small shoulder after 0.5h aging could be due to the presence of both amorphous (major constituent) and crystalline form. Further increase in aging time beyond color change caused the growth of crystallite particle size and resulted in wider distribution. During longer aging time partial dissolution and re-precipitation of precursor on other solids caused widening of PSD of the particles. In other words, the amorphous particles are less compact than crystalline particles and comprised aggregates of smaller particulates. Then, due to the dissolution and re-crystallization of particulates on crystal nucleates; crystallites with more compact and smaller size compared to the amorphous particles are produced. Upon further aging, crystallites grow further and there is a greater propensity for particle agglomeration. Fig. 3c shows the PSD of the precursor at different aging temperatures after 5h aging. Upon increasing the temperature, the average particle size decrease and the distribution becomes wider. Nucleation rate increases exponentially with supersaturation concentration, while the crystallite growth rate is closer to a linear function of supersaturation [22,23]. Therefore, higher supersaturation levels favor nucleation rather than crystal growth and result in the precipitation of highly dispersed material. At higher temperatures, supersaturation lowers and crystallite growth accelerates. Consequently, one expects that at 80°C the CuO crystallite size becomes larger than that at 60°C. From another point of view, as temperature increases, molecular fluctuations increase and molecules tend to escape from the nucleus, causing a decrease of nucleation rate. Fig. 3d shows the variation of PSD with stirring rate and concentration of initial solutions. As stirring rate increased from 500rpm to 1000rpm, PSD shifted to larger sizes. During precipitation, mixing reduce supersaturation of precipitating components by enhancing diffusion of the solute particles. During aging, mixing enhances the migration of precipitate from smaller to larger particles by reducing mass transfer limitation. Therefore, the particle size becomes larger by increasing stirring rate during precipitation and aging. It is expected that precipitation from more dilute solutions tends to produce fewer, but larger crystals due to lower nucleation rate. In agreement with this expectation, Fig. 3d shows that dilute solution caused wider distribution with the same average particle size. It should be noted that aggregation plays an important role. Aggregation leads to fewer and larger, but more porous particles. Aggregation is the formation of clusters of nanoscale primary particles into micrometer-scale secondary particles. It seems that dilute solution account for less aggregation of crystals, with result that particle size was decreased. The fact that mixing rate affects PSD implies that the overall process is mass transfer limited. Mixing induces nucleation, and also enhance growth rate, during precipitation. This results in a broad PSD. However, during aging, mixing increases growth rate by lowering mass transfer resistance between particles resulting in larger particles with sharper PSD. Lower concentrations decrease supersaturation and nucleation as well as growth, resulting in broader PSD with nearly the same average particle size. 3.2 Catalyst reduction Calcination of hydroxycarbonates converts them to CuO and ZnO oxides which are subsequently reduced by H2 to Cu. Most TPR profiles of the calcined precursors exhibited shoulders left to the main reduction peak. The shoulder peak and the main peak represent the reduction of surface CuO and bulk CuO, respectively [24]. Although the reduction of bulk ZnO is thermodynamically feasible at high temperatures, ZnO showed no distinct reduction peak. However, the possibility of partial reduction of surface ZnO, which may lead to formation of α-brass (dilute alloy of Zn in Cu) few layers thick on Cu crystallites has been proposed based on detailed thermodynamic calculations [25]. Fig. 4a shows the TPR profiles of the samples aged at 40°C after calcination. Although no evident color change observed, samples obtained from shorter aging precursors showed broader profiles shifted to high reduction temperatures. The characteristic shoulder is very small or absent. Samples with sharper PSD of precursors show lower reduction temperatures with sharper profiles. Fig. 4b shows the effect of aging time TPR profiles of the samples aged at 80°C after calcination. Longer aging time resulted in lower peak temperatures and boarder profile. Sample CZ06 obtained by shortest aging time with no color change exhibits highest reduction peak with no shoulder. Fig. 4c shows the effect of aging temperature after 5h aging on the TPR profile of the oxides. The sharpest peak was observed for CZ04 which had narrowest size distribution. Fig. 4d shows the effect of mixing rate and concentration on TPR profile of the samples aged at 60°C. Higher concentrations resulted in is sharper peaks with lower temperatures while higher mixing rate gave wider TPR profile with lower peak temperature. The results of TPR tests can be summarized in Fig. 5 which correlates the TPR peak temperature to CuO crystallite size. Larger CuO crystallites need higher reduction temperatures. The increase in TPR peak temperature with CuO crystallite size could be attributed to the increase of bulk to surface CuO ratio, with the latter needs higher reduction temperature as mentioned previously. The increase in crystallite size during the reduction of nano-sized Cu/ZnO catalysts indicated a pronounced sintering of copper particles (Fig. 6 ). Higher reduction temperatures (of larger CuO crystallites) accelerate sintering of CuO and Cu crystallites promoted by water formed from reduction [26]. Therefore, a linear relation between Cu and CuO crystallite size is not expected and an exponential-like relation is observed due to synergy of initially larger particles and more pronounced sintering (Fig. 6). As a consequence, achieving smaller crystallite size during precipitation and aging is critical to obtain catalysts with high performance. 3.3 Catalyst characterization and performance results Fig. 7 shows the effect of aging time on precursor particle size and CuO crystallite size (a), Cu surface area and catalyst STY (b), respectively for samples aged at 40°C. The particle size-D0.5 (called the median) is the size in microns that splits the distribution with half above and half below this diameter. The CuO crystallite size follows the same trend as particle size with aging temperature, while the STY follows similar trend to Cu surface area, showing the direct relation between each pair of the properties. Fig. 8 shows the effect of aging on precursor particle size and CuO crystallite size (a), Cu surface area and catalyst STY (b), respectively for samples aged at 80°C. The copper surface area and STY shows a maximum near color change time. According to a model proposed for nanostructured Cu/ZnO catalysts [9], increasing the aging time of the precipitate result in more homogeneous microstructure of the resulting Cu/ZnO catalysts which exhibit on average small Cu and ZnO crystalline sizes with narrow size distribution [27]. Apparently, prolonged aging produces well defined distribution of Cu and Zn in the hydroxycarbonates. Fig. 9 shows the effect of aging temperature after 5h aging on precursor particle size and CuO crystallite size (a), Cu surface area and catalyst STY (b), respectively. The copper surface area and STY shows a maximum around 60°C. CuO crystallite size parallels particle size of the precursors. As shown in Figs. 7–9, the STY of methanol parallels the CuO surface area. Fig. 10 shows the effect of Cu surface area on turnover frequency (TOF) of methanol synthesis. The TOF is defined as methanol molecules produced per unit surface copper atom per second [28]. The larger the surface area, the higher is the TOF implying that the reaction is structure sensitive. This can be explained by the fact that increase in surface area (decrease in particle size) results in enhanced contact and interfacial interaction between Cu and ZnO crystallites which increases the specific activity of the catalyst for methanol synthesis. According to the “active site creation model” ZnO provides Zn atoms on the Cu surface as active site for methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2 [29]. Further, Cu crystallite size could affect the ratio of different exposed Cu planes (e.g., Cu(110), Cu(200), etc.) with different intrinsic activities as observed in many other structure-sensitive reactions. These factor results an additional activity beyond that created by increasing surface area. 4 Conclusions The preparation conditions of Cu/ZnO hydroxycarbonate precursor have a strong effect on the performance of the final catalyst in methanol synthesis. Samples exhibited no color change, that is, transformation from initially amorphous precipitates into a mixture of crystalline rosasite and aurichalcite, showed poor catalytic performance. Performance test results showed at 40°C of aging temperature, activity of catalyst increased with aging time of precursors but the resulting catalyst exhibited poor activities because color change did not occur even after 65h of aging in the mother liquor. The activity of the catalysts increased with aging time and then decreased in longer aging times at 80°C. During aging the sharp pH drop along with color change (from blue to green) was observed after a certain time. It was found that this observation is due to structural changes of the precursors from initially amorphous precipitates transform into a mixture of crystalline rosasite and aurichalcite that exhibit higher performance in methanol activity. This transform was accelerated by increasing aging temperature, therefore it takes place at shorter times. After color change, further increase in aging time of precursor caused growth of crystallite size and decreasing the catalyst activity. It was also found for a constant aging time of precursor (5h), catalyst activity for methanol synthesis increases with temperature ranging from 40 to 60°C and then decrease when temperature raises further from 60 to 80°C. Precipitate aging time and temperature play important roles in determining the crystalline phase of the precursors and significantly effect on catalyst performance with respect to methanol high activity and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Binary Cu/ZnO methanol synthesis catalysts were prepared by the co-precipitation of copper and zinc hydroxycarbonates using different initial solution concentrations, stirring rates and aging times and temperatures during precipitation, and different calcination temperatures of the precipitated hydroxycarbonates. The precipitates (catalyst precursors), fresh catalyst and were characterized at appropriate stages by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm, X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), N2O chemisorption and particle size distributions measurement techniques. All catalysts were tested for methanol synthesis activity in fixed-bed reactor under conditions similar to that of commercial operation (503K, 50bar and GHSV of 17,250h−1), using of H2, CO, and CO2 (80/12/8mol ratio) mixture as the feed. During aging of the precursor, a sharp pH drop along with color change (from blue to green) was observed after certain aging time. Further, the particle size of precursors showed a decrease after color change. The time of this change was strongly dependent on the aging temperature and decreased by increasing aging temperature. At 40°C aging temperature, the catalyst activity increased with aging time but the resulting catalyst exhibited poor performance because the color change did not occur even after 65h of aging of the mother liquor. At 80°C aging temperature, a color change took place rapidly after about 0.5–0.75h of aging, and the catalyst activity increased with aging time followed by a decrease upon further aging. At a constant aging time of 5h, the catalyst activity increased with temperature in the range of 40–60°C and then decreased when temperature rose further from 60 to 80°C. The highest methanol synthesis activity (555gMeOH/kgcat h) was observed for the catalyst prepared from 1M initial solution, 500rpm stirring rate and aged at 60°C. This was attributed to the small CuO crystallite size and large Cu surface area of the resulting catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of precipitation conditions on precursor particle size distribution and activity of Cu/ZnO methanol synthesis catalyst
